It was a much-needed refresher on all of the countless science classes that used to leave me either bored or confused over the years. The book genuinely made me enjoy learning about each and every topic. This clever yet simple book has given me a fresh perspective and a newfound deep appreciation for the knowledge and achievements of science, and ultimately, for the beautiful world all around me.

Science was one of my favorite subjects in school. Learning science felt like you were learning the secrets of the world, like a magician telling you their secrets. But I was always confused by my scientific education. Typically, I was only given the facts but not the process. Sure, we know dinosaurs lived millions of years ago, but how do we know that? What gave us this incredible knowledge?The Magic of Reality is an incredible book. It is very well written. Dawkins does not dumb it down nor does he use superfluous scientific jargon. For example, he proposes a basic question like “What are things made of?” then goes about describing carefully what we know about atoms and how we know what we know. This book inspires me to learn more. It pushes me to think and rethink which is the essence of the scientific process. We should never be stagnant. There is a lot we don’t know, but this doesn’t mean the universe is unknowable instead it should push us to learn more.

I have secular humanist friends that find Dawkins condescending towards people of all religious faiths. These are my friends by the way that tend to agree with him on every point. Yet they know he did have a habit of trying to be annoying while he pointed out religion is a silly waste of time and people who have such beliefs are stupid. If you can get past Dawkins being Dawkins you might enjoy this book. It is a pretty solid introduction to high school science. Most likely review for anybody who has been alive a couple decades or more. Covered stuff like how tectonic plates move, how we calculate the distance from us on Earth to stars light-years away, how we know the age of the universe that is billions of years older than the Earth itself. It reminds me of “A Briefer History of Time.” Both books I wish I’d read perhaps before I was a freshman in high school.

This is a delightful book. Although it's aimed at younger readers, it's also perfectly readable for adults as well. Dawkins' writing style is personable and friendly, with a good helping of humour. He makes his subject easy for young readers to understand without being patronising, and helps the reader develop a sense of wonder at the natural world and the universe. Most importantly, he helps readers understand the scientific method and how we know what we know - increasingly important in the current anti-scientific climate. Although I was already familiar with a lot of the concepts covered, I still learned some new facts and ideas from this book, as well as new ways of looking at things. If I had children I wouldn't hesitate to let them read this; it's one of the nicest and most accessible science-based books I've read in years.

I had to stop after the first chapter.In that chapter, the author claims that Love is a product of the human brain and that it therefore did not exist before the human brain does...What does it say? The author is simply spiritually asleep. Anyone awake cannot possibly continue reading something so absurd.There's a wonderful definition of "real" that I heard from someone "Is real that which never changes". This means the author has it all upside down. To someone asleep the physical reality is the only thing that is real. To someone awake it is the only thing that isn't :) But of course the asleep person would find this statement insane because they cannot SEE.The title is misleading then, it should be "The magic of PHYSICAL reality" in which case I would probably not have picked the book.

"Science has its own magic: The magic of reality"Once again, a 5-star book from my favorite author, Richard Dawkins. Perhaps this is the clearest introduction to science I've ever read and definitely, I would love to recommend this book to every "non-science" person who wants to know how to make science interesting for them.This book is equipped with beautifully-written myths and legends from various traditional tales at the beginning of most chapters that might be familiar to some readers. Afterward, it tries to elaborate on the scientific explanation behind those stories and show the magic of reality. It is magic because it is real.It took a while for me to finish this book. Not because it is long and difficult to understand but the opposite: it is very easy to understand and it makes me want to "feel" every sentence written in this book mindfully.

If you're not a scientist, or have taken higher level science classes, this is the book for you. It's very simple, straightforward explanations of common occurrences in the world, and how science and you as a non-scientist can deduce fiction from reality using logic without having to know calculus.Richard Dawkins is just brilliant. This is also amazing for any young adult, teenager or even preteen because the artwork is GORGEOUS in the book and it keeps the reader's attention throughout the book.I cannot recommend this book to EVERYONE.P.S. I'm a high school science teacher (biology, chemistry and physics) and I have 5 copies of this book on my shelf in the classroom to lend to any of my students who are curious about how to determine fiction and fact.

Having been required to read Dawkins' The Ancestors Tale for an introductory bio class in high school, I was excited to be able to read another of his works without a deadline looming over my head. I expected another intellectual trek into the world of science and, although a bit disappointed at the level of knowledge expected of the reader, I think Dawkins did a phenomenal job of showing all of the beauty of science in the natural world. As a Biology major halfway through his undergraduate career, it was so refreshing to read about a biologist acknowledging all of the wonders beyond the world we live on. Written at such a comprehensible level for readers with no science background, Dawkins wrote one of the best love letters to science that I've read in a while.

This book is arguably the best introduction to science ever written. Beautiful written and the reader can't help but to share Dawkins enthusiasm for the wonder of science. The book is suitable for all ages, but perhaps especially for young readers (or someone who've never read a science book before). The explanations are easy to follow for anyone, and the book is hard to put down.I've read my fair share of science books, so there might not have been anything new to learn from this book. In that sense I could only wish this book was my first introduction to science. Still enjoyed it a lot, and especially the chapter introductions with the ancient mythical explantions. I recommend this book to everyone!

One of the most enjoyable books to read. As a teacher, it's great to have a more in depth information and explanation for scientific ideas, which is always fun to describe to younger pupils. The thought experiments throughout the book were interesting to do as well (I found myself holding up my finger to show the 'parallax' experiment while reading in the company of my housemates, who looked at me as though I was a bit strange!) I do feel that this is a book I've read 10 years too late. It's regretful that I didn't come across this book as a teenager in school, to inspire me through my own studies in science and applied maths classes. Thankfully, it's never too late to learn from books of this calibre. I would recommend this book to anyone from age 12 upwards.

If for some reason you missed or have forgotten all of GCSE science then this book is for you. Rudimentary descriptions of basic science left me feeling bored; evolution, probability, causation, molecules, matter, planetary orbits, stars, rainbows, light, extra-terrestrial life, earthquakes and plate tectonics. The only thing this book taught me or rather made me remember, as I’ve read about it in Hawking’s ‘A Briefer History Of Time’, is why illustrations of the Doppler effect are red and blue due to red and blue shift. Dawkins has the ability to pitch his writing at different levels for example at my level such as 'The Selfish Gene' and 'The God Delusion' and above my head such as 'The Extended Phenotype' (I’m not a biologist) and so I only wish they’d come with a warning label so I knew which ones to bother reading.

“The magic of reality is neither supernatural nor a trick, but – quite simply – wonderful. Wonderful, and real. Wonderful because real.” When I bought this book, I had no clue it was intended for younger audiences. However, despite that fact, it was an enjoyable read. (The childlike wonder is the most appropriate reaction to scientific phenomena, after all. )Sure, the tone was kid-friendly and he covered basic stuff most adults already know, but I cherish every opportunity to be in awe of the magic of the mundane and this book certainly offered it. If you have a kid or know a kid that’s under 14 years of age, this book would make a great gift. In fact, in an ideal world, this would be a part of assigned reading list.

This book was not what I expected. Specifically, the first half of this book is a collection of primers on basic science lessons which, if you graduated from high school in the United States, you already will know. I already was familiar with the structure of an atom, and I knew what DNA is, I know what a rainbow is and how prisms work. I don’t want to hold this against the book because maybe that is what it was intending to be and for someone without a basic science education, maybe it will be helpful.The second half of the book was more interesting. It focused on ancient myths and how they explain things like miracles and religious dogma. But overall, this book was totally underwhelming. If you are looking for something akin to a philosophical treatise, look elsewhere.

Very clear and easy introduction to science. The concepts are explained in a very easy to understand way, and show how what we do know about reality is in itself such a revelation and wonder that there is really no need for some myth or religious explanation in addition. I did not give it a 5 star because the text is sometimes too much directed at a child reader. Adults though will find this book very insightful and certainly will come away with new understandings.I wish I had this book when I was at school. It should be required reading for every 12-16 year old as it opens up the wonders of science without any boring technicalities that need to be memorised or exercises to work through.

I enjoyed it, as I have much of Dawkins' other works. I love his style and language (This is what engaged me so much when I first read his most well-known and controversial work 'The God Delusion') as well as his thorough and clear explanation of certain ideas. However, few of the scientific concepts presented were novel to me. If you have a reasonable understanding of fundamental scientific principles they won't be to you either. That said, it was an enjoyable read nonetheless, and one that was well deserving of the four stars I gave it. This is the kind of book I would gift or recommend to an audience slightly younger than myself, maybe in their mid teens. Thankyou Richard Dawkins for another interesting read.

It's a bit baffling how much humans use magical thinking in their day to day life. Yet, I used to be great at using this awful tool. And then when you learn why and how people use magical thinking, it seems so obvious what you were doing! I simply wish more people read books like this so they'd stop projecting their magical thinking beliefs onto me. "Maybe it happened for a reason!""See! This is what you needed right now!""It's a sign!!"Just keep your little merry beliefs to yourself. I prefer to live in reality. Keep up the good work Richard! Books like these are great at exposing the underlying issues and lies people like to tell themselves and are helping people wake up from lifelong cult ideologies. Or at least, they did for me :) And for that I am very grateful.

In this book, Richard Dawkins explains nature phenomena, like rainbow, earthquakes, day and night, in an easy-to-understand manner. He also gives a good analogy of how natural selection and evolution works by giving a thought experiment of us stacking our ancestors' photo. I'd say the explanation really helps for younger audiences or people who aren't familiar with the topic. He also tells some myths related to the thing discussed in the chapter to show how people used to create myths or folklores to explain things they didn't understand. In general, this book is a light reading for everyone who wants to find a simple yet still accurate explanation of world phenomena. It may also be useful to help you explain things to kids in an easy-to-understand way.

The book explores a wide range of natural phenomena through inspiring explanations of space, time and evolution laced with humor and clever thought experiments. In many of these, he also enumerates the conventional myths and tales of supernatural phenomena before providing his explanations based upon scientific enquiry. What is stuff made of? How old is the universe? What causes earthquakes? Who was the first man or woman? The book mines Science for its clues and also guides the reader to think like a scientist.I have read quite a few books of the author and found them interesting to read. However, in my opinion, this is easily his best writing and in a simple language for a lay person to understand.

Dawkins ascribes magic to 3 categories: Stage Magic, Charlatans, and Reality. He emphasizes the beauty of the last category throughout the book, and understandably so. His book is divided into chapters through which he addresses a selection of different topics where people might have difficulty separating myth from reality.A good bit of this might be 'obvious' to some readers, but others might take offense to his candid treatment of other sensitive subjects, such as religion. To help enable acceptance, the subtitle of the book "How We Know What's Really True" is frequently revisited throughout.Even if you find this difficult, on the basis of your principles or otherwise, I encourage all readers to persist.

"The truth has a magic of its own." Despite being already familiar with most of the scientific answers he compellingly provided for these simple—yet essential— questions, and for which most people have a biased understanding or none, I must say that I have enjoyed this reading and recommend it to a general readership. Two of the things I value the most about this author are: (1) his notorious detachment from religion in the pursuit of truth and (2) his stupendous communication skills for getting science abstractions across the general public which, at the same time, benefits a much needed science advocacy. I have an appreciation for his eloquence.

The reviews of this book were better than the actual book. Although, after about 100 pages, I recalled one reviewer mentioning something about "young adults", perhaps as the target audience? I had heard what a great science writer Dawkins is, and had expected more. But most of the science being explained was what I remember from, I think, High School science classes. But it has lots of great pictures! So the last half of the book, I just skimmed the text for things I didn't already know, and enjoyed the graphics. Chapter 9 had some interesting things in it worth reading closely. Overall, I can only recommend it to adults as being a fun graphic science review, like an adult comic book.

A good intro to pop-science. If you studied science in high school and were a curious student or have read pop-science books on evolution, universe, general science etc, you may be familiar with most of the things in this book and yet it is worth a read because of the simplistic and beautiful manner in which author explains things. Author starts with ancient myths surrounding scientific facts and then explains the reality in a very simple and concise way.I guess, it is better suited for teenagers or people starting with pop-science. Its a great start and provides general overview of universe, evolution and many more basic things such as optics, rainbows etc.

3.5/5. A solid introduction to the world of science and the concept of scientific thinking.It showcases the reasoning behind various everyday occurrences and acts as a primer for the fields of evolutionary biology, chemistry etc which form the basis of human life in the 21st century.Dawkins goes to great lengths to dispell a huge variety of myths that humans have concocted to explain mysterious events like the origins of life and natural disasters.Overall, it's a book aimed at a younger audience and thus, it can even appeal to people without a scientific background. Get this book and get rid of a good deal of the myths you were brought up to believe in!

In this book, Dawkins provides a great primer for scientific inquiry. It is the ideal book to get adolescent minds interested in science and thinking critically about the world and their experiences. He starts each chapter with myth and then provides the scientific explanation. The Magic of Reality is aptly named. At times, the explanations of reality of our natural world was more astounding and enjoyable than the myth. He also does a fantastic job of tying in different concepts throughout the book. One note- this book is intended for a younger audience, something of which I was initially unaware. The first few chapters especially cover basic, introductory concepts of science.

A concise and interesting look at science and its superseding of myth. Overall, Dawkins provides a solid summary of modern science principles alongside his standard, mildly bewildered view that illogical myths remain alive to this day. I was surprised Dawkins didn't reference the Homunculus as a proto-myth akin to germ theory; though of medieval origin, it is an enticing mythical imagining of the very tiny. I enjoyed Dawkin's narration, though I wonder if a slightly more understanding position might register a greater win for science...then again, were it presented with no vinegar at all perhaps no one would pay attention.

Genuinely can't decide if I like this or not. Either I know more science than I gave myself credit for, or the intended audience of this book is teenagers trying to look smart. I didn't take science seriously at school, which I regret, but even with the little knowledge I have nothing in here is really new to me. Though I appreciate the thought experiments. Like in the chapter about the sun, he references photosynthesis but just says 'and plants get energy from the sun' it wouldn't have been completely appropriate to briefly explain photosynthesis but it didn't happen. I don't much like pop-psychology pop-philosophy or pop-anything but this really feels like pop-science.

The book is written in an easy and compressive manner. It gives a good overview  with scientific explanation of a variety of common myths and folklore. It appears to me a good read for someone who has some understanding of science but is not keen on going in depth. The purpose of the book however doesn't appear to be a mere scientific description of certain physical phenomena; but to plot the beauty of the true scientific explanations of those phenomena against the ignorance of supernatural myths that roam in our societies. Something that a book successfully achieves by describing those myths and then giving the magical scientific explanations in each chapter.

I'm a fan of Dawkins so this book was immediately an interest to grab. After the first few chapters I realized o should be sharing it with my 8yo, so we read it together. Dawkins does an amazing job of explaining complex subjects in an easy to grasp way. Whether it's his analogies or how he approaches it my kiddo could understand it well enough to carry on in a conversation about it with me. I really appreciate solid science communicators and he is so much more than just that. Thank you for all your work throughout the years. Fighting & debunking myths, educating so many and helping us all to discover the magic of reality.

I would be giving this book a 4 star rating, if there wasn't an urgent need for a lot of people to read it. The boredom in the educational system created individuals who don't believe in science and judge that which they don't understand thus creating a big need for this kind of messages. In this book Richard Dawkins cleverly and compellingly explains some of the mysteries of the world that allured people for thousands of years. It is written in a easily understandable language with many plain comparisons and amusing explanations. Recommend to everyone. Even my scientific friends will gain something by reading this.

Three stars is not my usual rating for Richard Dawkins at all. It is not the fault of the quality of the book - had I looked further than the author I would have understood it was written for a younger crowd. It will be a five star recommendation for my own daughter when she is a few years older (maybe 13-14?), but I suppose I went into it expecting the poetic and thoughtful and mind-blowing that always comes with Richard Dawkins, but this was an awe-inspiring introduction to younger readers which could not teach me anything new. Definitely still a wonderful read.

The Magic of Reality is an interesting introduction to basic science concepts written in a way even older children could easily follow. Unique and interesting about this work is how the author opens each chapter with an ancient myth. Some of the myths are from natives tribes and from all over the world ranging from bizarre to amusing. This illustrates how humankind has always grappled with not yet understood natural phenomena. However, the chapters' science parts will not introduce much new knowledge to an educated reader due to their extremely basic nature.

Lent to me by a friend, this was a nice read. As a scientist, there were no new concepts in here for me, however I think Dawkins did a very good job of explaining complex systems in an easy to understand manner, without patronising the reader. His writing is flavoured with his distinctive style, such that I can envision is impassioned pleas while reading it. I think a lot of people would enjoy reading this book and learning or upgrading their knowledge in subjects we should all appreciate in our modern world.

This book is super entertaining. I wish I could rate 2 1/2. 50% I loved it. 50% was scientifically dramatic. But hey! I enjoyed it!The book is informative and is worth it, but I still have doubts, for example, The sun born 4.5 billion years ago. Planet Earth is 4.5 billion years old. Why they both share the same birthday? Why? Perhaps because the story started with: “in the beginning?” Did you hear poetry?...Moreover, we started writing and reading 5,000 years ago. What happened before? Maybe a light from the sky made us smarties:) only five thousand years ago?

3.5 stars. When I was a kid, I had a book called Disaster Science that I read cover to cover, over and over again. The Magic of Reality reminded me a lot of that, with the same kind of clear explanations and vivid illustrations. I wish I'd had it growing up.I docked a star because sometimes it was hard to tell what age group this was really geared for, and I would have arranged the chapters a little differently.

I am a fan of Richard Dawkins and picked this up used when I was bored, not realizing it was written for kids. Unfortunately, the copy I have doesn’t have illustrations. Since I already have a pretty good scientific background, I skimmed through it. It’s nearly a decade old and a few new things have been learned but it’s a good overview of what science has taught us, how life works, and our place in the universe. My husband, the non-scientist, liked it a lot. I will now hand it on to a 13-year old friend.

Good science writing achieves poetic status, and this Dawkins book (nominally for young adults, but really for anyone who wants to experience genuine expositive clarity) is a great example of How To Do It. While Dawkins' other popular science books (as opposed to his scientific papers, atheist manifesti, or biographical writing) are denser and more tightly focused on particular aspects of evolutionary biology, this is a broad general survey that offers a very good introduction to scientific ways of thinking. I love this book.

After “ the selfish genes” I strive to finish all the books Richard Dawkins ever written. This is the second one which aims for younger readers. This book covers a lot: biology, chemistry, cosmology, physic and probability. Some of the chapters are harder than the others for me, which gives me a reminder on which knowledge I need to brush up. I love this book, not by the explanations on different topics but the emphasis on the importance of scientific reasoning and how one should approach religion and mysteries we cannot explanation – a framework for understanding how knowledge fits together - with rigor, rationality and curiosity. “The truth is more magical—in the best and most exciting sense of the word—than any myth or made-up mystery or miracle.

This book takes ideas and events that you have always accepted as is and actually made you think about them. Earthquakes, stars, etc. Dawkins also really opened up my mind to just how big the world is, and how much we still have to discover. It was interesting because I really think this book gave me a whole new perception of the world around me. The only thing I didn't enjoy about this book is that each chapter started with common myths, just because I wasn't really interested in that. Overall very thought provoking and I definitely wsnt to read more of his work.

“The truth is more magical - in the best and most exciting sense of the word - than any myth or made-up mystery or miracle. Science has its own magic: the magic of reality"...I think this extract from the book says almost everything about this book. I personally feel that Richard Dawkins is such an author who knows exactly how to capture the attention of his readers. I am pretty sure most of the readers become his fan just reading a few chapters from his books, and I am one of them. Ever since I read "The God Delusion", I became a RD fan.Magic of Reality is an attempt to reveal few magical secrets of the universe, analyzing the scientific realm of reality with reasoning, logic and explanations, making a comparison of some of the naturally occurring universal phenomenon against the backdrop of Science and the age old Myths & Superstitions. But one think I must confess that this book did not meet the standard of my expectation as compared to his other books. I expected this book to contain with some more chapters, revealing some more magical perspectives of the universe. But to my surprise the book ended rather too early as if Mr Dawkins got some better ideas to work on and abandoned the Magic halfway across the universe.

Great book for young curious minds. It covers diverse subjects from physics, cosmology and other. It is a nice book to be handed to a young adolescent to spark curiosity, but not advanced enough for people who went through some scientific books and courses. For science enthusiasts it a may be a good recollection and entertaining depiction of myths vs science, but not a book to learn new things from.

I like listening to audio books about evolution, and I enjoyed this book, but there were some things I didn't like: the author was condescending at times ("you won't understand this", "some people can't understand this"), several times the author said "this is really interesting but I won't explain it", and there were some really simple things that got explained in this audiobook (like how rainbow is formed) that made me think it is designed for young people?

Excellent art and subjects that are discussed. Only one weakness, Dawkins conveys a speech of absolutes. This can be unwelcoming to others trying to be open minded. My guesses is that he had struggles with people on the religious end and unfortunately was ‘hurt’ by them. In the end a brilliant man with brilliant theories. We must always leave a benefit for doubt in all cases, even to the most extreme degrees. And we’re welcome not to believe in the opposing side.

Metaphysics in 21 century from a scientist. Really? Otherwise, the book is well written and introduces the achievements of science in an understandable for regular people language. The style is engaging. I find popular science quite entertaining ,but when I see a pompous headline that includes 'truth' or other category or ethics in something that is related to natural science, that's a clear indicator that there will be some metaphysical misconception going on.

Enjoyable reading, although nothing new for a high school graduate (or should not be at least) or anyone with a sincere interest about the World around us, but provides plenty of stories and enjoyable narratives on how to explain a rainbow, earthquake, sun or many other things to your kids. I´d recommned this book to any teenager or anyone who wants to read enjoyable book about (prevalently) natural science.

If you are science educated then you might not (will not) find this book very useful. But the audience for this book aren't supposed to have a very good understanding of scientific methods. For them the book is a must read. People who "believe" in things and in supernatural events/beings will do good to themselves by reading this book. Richard Dawkins has definitely shown that the "magic" of reality is far more enchanting than the fairy or stage magic!

I didn't know this book was aimed more at younger kids when I rented it from the library (It wasn't shelved in the kids' section!), but I still found some of the topics informative. Dawkins opens each of the chapters telling ancient myths that were used to "explain" certain events, (the day/night cycle, how rainbows are formed, what causes earthquakes, etc.) then goes into the actual science behind them. Definitely recommended for younger readers who are interested in science!

One of the best books I have read in science. I liked the idea of telling a historical story and then discussing it in a scientific way. The author started the book giving us the principles which we need to understand the rest of the book. That's what makes this book easy to read for everyone.I would recommend this book to everyone interested in science and it could be a good introduction for the ones who had no experience in this field.

An interesting book to be sure, but lacking in certain departments. It kinda feels all over the place, without much reference to the overarching goal.Although that could have gone over my head.What I mainly missed was how the human body interprets the data from our senses. And how our reality is subjective: there are many animals that can see or hear a much wider range of colors or sounds that we do.

I so wish this book had been available as a kid. I would have had a much better life because I would not have wasted so much time on religion and superstitions. And the art was incredible. I suppose I should write a longer review, but there's not much of a point. Go read it.

This book wasn’t quite what I expected, but a good read nonetheless. He touches on the myths that had been told regarding many natural phenomena before discussing the evidence of how those things actually happen in our world. Some examples are rainbows, starlight, and genetics. He briefly touches on the basic concepts of a broad range of these topics, so this book is more of a science primer than a deep dive into any one concept.

First Dawkins book that I wouldn’t recommend. Really light on content. Did he just mail this was in, have a ghost-writer?? Not much insight here, more like the musings of a smart gent written down over a long weekend. Perhaps this was intended for young readers, with the unveiled exhortation to question your religion. While I’d agree with that, the God Delusion sufficiently handled that topic. That said, I can’t get myself to dip below a passing grade of 3 stars for Dawk.

I didn't finish this book, quitting midway through chapter four. I don't know if this book was intended for middle schoolers or maybe adults with pretty much no scientific knowledge, but I thought the writing came across as almost condescending. I think it would be a great book for 10-12 year olds, but I just wasn't enjoying it, and my to-read list is too long to insist on finishing books I'm not enjoying.

This book ought to deserve 5 stars, but it's full of sentences like this:"The elements are conveniently set out in a table called the periodic table---I won't go into why it's called that, although it's interesting."It's infuriating that Dawkins can't make science simple without mutilating the details. This is presumably a book for children, and I can't see how this approach is supposed to get them excited to learn more, when Dawkins continuously refuses to complete his explanations.

definitely not for me.to be honest, this one is a really good science communication book. Dawkins wrote everything in a simple language yet everything is well-described. i think this will suit for a general audience, or as a bedtime story for your kids aged up to 15 or just to help them understanding science in a non-boring, relatable way (unlike the confusing textbooks we all ever had in elementary school). but this comes with a price in which it slows down the pace and removes the thoroughness that i wished to see.

The writer tries to explain simply 12 scientific topics from evolution to miracles. Starting every chapter with a myth about the topic he illustrates, then he tries to interpret briefly the phenomenon he is writing about.The last two lines in the last chapter give a good idea about the content:the truth is more magical in the best and most exciting sense of the word than any myth or made-up mystery or miracle. Science has its own magic the of reality.

This sort of started off okay. Basic mansplaining of scientific concepts. Then it kind of took a turn for the worst IMO. Completely shat on ancient indigenous knowledge and wisdom.. Passing it off as fairytales that are simply ridiculous and something that science can explain away. It's cool if that's how you think and what you feel, but shitting on others beliefs kinda just passes over the line for me. So this books a nope from me.

I am fan of his writing i have read his most famous books on biology.As a biologist he talked lot more about the space and the current reality what we go through and some of his phrases are funny.we humans live nearly 60 to 80 years on earth we ruin our life deciding what is bad and good and we already believe somethings before we experiment.this book not chnges your mindset and only talks about whats real the true reality.Everyday is science

I love how this book is so easy to read and brings to life concepts in such a digestible way. I wish it covered more breadth/other concepts and some of the text at the beginning of each chapter about myths believed by different communities around the world was shorter. I didn’t care much to read about that but can see how it’s the authors way of emphasising the ridiculousness of believing in how things work without any factual basis, as some of the myths mentioned sound quite outlandish.

the blue pill.easy to digest version of god delusion.mesmerizing and informative.touches topics widely and not too deeply.useful for children and adults who want to participate in the joy of living in reality.chapters introduce topic, 'mythical explanation' and then scientific explanation. fantastic job in organization.another beautiful work of Richard Dawkins.

The style of Dawkins' writing was easy to follow and enjoyable to read. However, as both a physics student, and a Christian, I was seriously disappointed in the shallowness of his scientific arguments and his misrepresentation of biblical scripture. I would encourage the interested reader to look a little deeper into his statements and do some research, rather than take them at face value.

This is really written for 11 to 15-year-olds, but it's also a nice introduction to some of the basic science questions for everyone who doesn't know them. For me, it was too basic, although Dawkins explanations are quite interesting and easily absorbed. I would recommend this to anyone who has delusions of some kind or doesn't know how to answer those simple questions themselves.

Excellently written with a surprising ability to anticipate the questions that would crop up in any layman's mind while reading the pages and answering them in short succession right along. Dawkins is as brilliant a mind as the best in the field, but his writing beats even the best! Incredible book for kids and adults.

This is one of my favorite books of all time. He is, as always, clear and concise. Each chapter poses a question. He then begins by displaying how various myths have attempted to explain and "answer" the question. He then goes into clear detain about how science has, and always will have, the better and more satisfying answer. This book should be required reading for all teenagers.

Richard Dawkins has the unusual power of not only making complex scientific ideas easy to understand, he writes then with a modern day elegance that takes you to new periods in history and new places in the galaxy. If you want to understand our place in the universe through evolution, and time and space, spare a few days to read this amazingly enlightening book.

A wonderful small book that tackle so many subjects concerning the world we live in . In the routine of our daily lives it is important to stop for a while and think about our galaxy and it's place in space ,our belief systems ,evolution , in short to stop rushing about (and being the slave of our cell phone less) and wonder about the "magic" of what we are made of and what is around us .

although a fan of Richard Dawkins, this book left me a bit meh. The science in this book is basic secondary school. The author mentions on multiple occasions that he doesn't know enough of the topic to go deeper in to it. Best part of the book were the references to the different world myths, trying to explain things.

I'm 18 years old. I do think you should either be younger or less invested into science to read this. Otherwise, you'll be disappointed by not having learned something new, or you'll be bored and find yourself skipping the pages.The book is great. The message is wonderful. For the explanations I am merely the wrong audience.

Dawkins uses simple language to explain quite complex scientific theories. The tone is light and conversational so it’s easy to read.The pictures are beautiful and really add to the text, and the myths at the start of the chapters are really interesting.It’s a basic understanding of biology, chemistry and physics and should inspire someone to look further into the topics covered.

Great read. Intended for a younger audience, but I still gleaned new bits of info. Especially useful was Hume's premise for identifying miracles (they are more probable than any other possible explanation), which I find could work just as well to combat the rising tide of conspiracy theorists and deniers in my classroom.

This is about a ninth grade general science level explanation of our best current general understanding of nature. It also contains one of Dawkins' gentler critiques of religion, especially Christianity. This would be a good recommendation for high school kids of average ability, with the hope that they will be motivated to ask for fuller explanations.

Twere exhilarating! I now agree that the truth has a magic of its own. I enjoy reading the myths and e'en I enjoy more the science facts. This book explaining science's present understanding of reality and explanations. It is accessible for young reader like me, I consider this book as a easy reading book.

A great introduction to what modern science knows in many different fields. The stark comparison between scientific explanations and previously held myths as explanations is what makes this book great. It teaches on every page yet also reminds us not to fall victim to supernatural manmade beliefs that have plagued mankind.

This is delightful primer on the beauties of science. I chose it for our office book club read because it was recommended reading by Bill Gates. Dawkins’s overzealous view of religion aside, his passion for science, logic and reasoning comes through in his writing, and he makes it easy and fun, which puts him at the same table as Carl Sagan and Neil deGrasse Tyson in my book.

A well-written book that explains complex things in a simple way. This book helped me relearn a lot that I had forgotten in school and learn many new things. Although I might not have agreed with Dawkins on everything, I enjoyed his ability to challenge my views. This book is an excellent introduction to science that nearly everyone could get something out of.

Dawkins is the science teacher I wish I had. If you’ve ever struggled with scientific topics at school, give this a read. Dawkins has a beautiful articulacy that allows him to succinctly explain complex scientific concepts. After almost every chapter I found myself pausing with awe at the magic of reality!

This is an excellent group of essays about the world and how we know the things that we do. There is information about myths, religious beliefs, and the evidence offered by science. It gives great data about exactly how the discoveries were made. It also discusses the similarities between the beliefs of different cultures.

This book is suppose to be for children but many adults, including myself, need to read this book. It talks about the very basic science( physics, chemistry, astronomy, Biology) in very simple terms. each chapter starts with several ancient myth about natural phenomena and the the real reason for their occurrence is explained. Richard Dawkins has a way with teaching, it is exceptionally good.

I personally loved this book. I liked the theme of the book in the way it was laid out. It gives you multiple myths about a certain subject and then takes you on a journey in easy to understand language, in showing how we know what is true and supports it with evidence as opposed the myths on the subject.

While this book does contain a list of topics that are essential for the commoners to understand, the author does not delve deeper into the complex subjects. Readers with little or less knowledge on science subjects may find it intriguing enough, while avid readers with higher appetite might wanna continue their quest for something better.

This is a great book that explains different types of scientific principles in simple terms for your average joe.It also portrays information in a enjoyable way , instead of presenting facts in a rigid, and purely academic method.I highly suggest readers with very basic knowledge of science to read this book.

A quick read, I got through it in 3 evenings. It's targeted towards a younger audience so it's certainly one of Dawkins easier books to pick up. I enjoyed it, it flowed well and kept me interested throughout. I particularly liked how he often started chapters with myths from various religions around the world and then proceeded to debunk them with simple science.

This book is intended for a much younger reader, 9-13 years I would say, which I realised only after having started reading it. The simplicity of language was a welcome change. Richard Dawkins has explained topics like formation of rainbows, plate tectonics, Doppler effect etc with clarity and with the help of simple analogies. A wonderful book with an apt title.

even though this is a book that is intended for younger readers, i still recommend it for every one.it answers some of the most common scientific questions and offers valuable explanation about topics in biology, geology, cosmology and evolution of course.i mean this book is by richard dawkins nuff said ! ...

our society believes in myth and science shall be the way to cure it. i have always liked dawkins' writing. the explanation was very well delivered. shout out to dave mckean's beautiful artwork. i myself literally enjoyed it."We should always be open-minded, but the only good reason to believe that something exists is if there is real evidence that it does." (p. 16)
